This program, which is part of the CARES Act, provides up to 39 weeks of Unemployment Insurance benefits for those who are self-employed, independent contractors, gig economy workers, those who have exhausted their regular and extended benefits and others.

We reported 8 new cases of COVID-19 today. Nearly two-thirds of the state's confirmed cases have fully recovered. The 14-day self-quarantine directive will now expire on May 8 and camping at State Parks campgrounds will begin to open on May 15 for Wyoming residents only.

Our Unemployment Office is working quickly to implement expanded benefits available under the CARES Act. These include an extension of regular unemployment, additional funding for those eligible, and the expansion of benefits for self-employed or contract employees.

I have also issued a directive requiring any individual coming to Wyoming for a non-work-related purpose to immediately self-quarantine for 14 days. Visitors from neighboring states have strained the resources of our communities and put public health at risk.

The period of self-quarantine continues to begin at the time of arrival through 14 days or for the duration of the visit ‚Äì whichever is shorter. All arriving travelers will be required to comply w/ all applicable state ; county rules, directives ; orders.

This was not an easy decision. I know this has been difficult for everyone. Businesses need to reopen. People want to end this self-isolation and we want to return to normal. But this virus is potentially deadly, especially for the elderly and those with pre-existing conditions.

While home, it's important to also remember the importance of self-care. Before grabbing a good book or turning on the television, we encourage you to take a deep breath...breathing in slowly through your nose then exhaling through your mouth. Ready...set...breathe.

Contact tracing is when we reach out to those who may have been exposed to  to notify them of their exposure and make sure they have the resources they need to get tested, get additional health care, and be able to stay home for the period that they could become sick.

How do case investigations work? For every person who tests positive, we reach out and inform them of their diagnosis and ensure that they have what they need to stay home safely. In addition, they will be asked about every person they may have been in contact with.

Secretary Erik Hooks: Since March 1st, 9% or 16 juveniles have been released from youth development centers back to their home or to a community-based step-down program.
Secretary Erik Hooks: Prior to releasing any juvenile from a YDC, staff must ensure the home and community environments are safe and supportive of the juvenile‚Äôs continued growth.
Secretary Erik Hooks: We are also working to safely return juveniles committed to long term youth development centers to their home communities.

.: We are continuing to acquire personal protective equipment. Surgical masks and gloves are two items where we do have some supplies and we are pushing those out to hospitals, first responders and long-term care homes.

.: Flash flooding has subsided in our western counties, but not before leaving washed out roads and mudslides in a few places. Last night, water rescue crews helped people escape from some flooded homes in Watauga and Haywood counties.

.: Sadly, one person has died in these storms. A 61-year-old Davidson County woman died this morning when a tree fell on her mobile home. Our prayers are with her family, and her husband, who suffered minor injuries.
.: Staying home now saves lives and puts us in a position of strength as we prepare for a new normal.

.: Thank you, Governor. It‚Äôs worth repeating what the Governor said. North Carolinians are staying home to save lives. We are keeping our families safe, our health care workers safe, and our communities safe.

. Governor: And to those who cannot stay home ‚Äì our doctors, nurses, hospital staff, grocery workers, first responders, law enforcement, delivery drivers, early childhood educators, sanitation workers, public health staff, farmers, and so many more ‚Äì thank you.
. Governor: You probably never even thought about having the power to bend the curve of a global pandemic ‚Äì but you do. As long as you stay home to stay safe.

. Governor: But most of all ‚Äì we are staying at home to save lives. I know many days feel difficult in this new, temporary world in which we find ourselves. But please know, when you hit those bumpy spots, that what you are doing to stay home really matters.
. Governor: Parents have become home schoolteachers. Schoolteachers have found even more creative and important ways to support their students.
. Governor: What we are doing is working. We are saving lives. Our biggest enemy is complacency. The better we can be at staying home through April, the more likely we are able to ease restrictions.

.: 76% of all of RI's COVID deaths occurred in our nursing homes, compared to 62% in MA and 57% in CT. The situation in nursing homes across the country is tragic. This virus is particularly difficult for older people, and it spreads quickly in cong. care settings.

Dr. A-Scott: We have completed 2 rounds of testing at all nursing homes, and tested at roughly 20 homes as part of our third round of testing. Between last week and this week, our number of new resident cases in long term care facilities decreased from roughly 575 to roughly 370.
Dr. A-Scott: We have completed 2 rounds of cyclical testing in nursing homes, testing all residents in all nursing homes (roughly 7,500 people in 85 nursing homes) in a regular rotation.

We are working with nursing homes + assisted living facilities to developed limited visitation policies for Phase 3. We are working collaboratively with hospitals to develop plans to allow for visitation safely in Phase 3. We are relaxing visitation for other cong. care settings.

As we begin the process of Opening Up America Again, we will be aggressively focused on early  case recognition, isolation, and contact tracing. These are the fundamentals of public health that we continue to implement to keep our Nation open.

. is spending a lot of time expanding the US public health capacity to enhance early case recognition, isolation, ; contact tracing for . We will need a strong public health capacity to open the US back up, county-by-county, and to stay open.

. is preparing for the possible seasonality of  by improving our public health capacity for early case identification, isolation and contact tracing. For any future waves, we will be able to contain AND mitigate.

Reopening the US will be a careful, data-driven, county-by-county approach. We have to substantially enhance our public health capacity to do early case identification, isolation and contact tracing. We must also build confidence in the community to reopen.

‚Ä¢ Disaster declaration: Ensures we have access to all necessary resources to support response to this pandemic. It is more important than ever that we are prepared to respond quickly with testing, contact tracing and quarantine and isolation supports.

Dr. A-Scott: We were able to identify 4,000+ positive cases at the Twin River site, which meant that we were able to get these people into isolation very quickly, and were able to get their contacts in quarantine very quickly. We want testing to be as accessible as possible.

if your respiratory symptoms have improved, you are okay to come out of isolation. That means it is safe to go back to work. This is based on science from the CDC. CDC researchers are not finding evidence of transmissible virus after this 10-day period has lapsed.

Dr. A-Scott: 3-pronged approach (SOS):
1. Symptomatic Testing: Test + get them into isolation right away if positive
2. Outbreak Rapid Response: Using testing as one part of a comprehensive response to outbreaks in higher risk settings
3. Expanding Sentinel Early Warning System

Dr. A-Scott: It includes translation services, expanded testing, contact tracing, and quarantine + isolation supports. Public health has a responsibility to call out racism and systems that are discriminatory. Learn about the work of Health Equity Zones at

Dr. A-Scott: Testing people who have symptoms quickly means that we can get them into isolation quickly. It also allows us to do contact tracing and get people‚Äôs contacts into quarantine as soon as possible, all of which helps stop the ripples of spread.

‚Ä¢ If you received a negative test result but have symptoms, you still need to self-isolate. That means even doing whatever you can to be in separate space from the people in your own household.

Dr. A-Scott: 1 area that we can start to focus on a little more is to really make sure that we are following the quarantine, isolation, and contact tracing guidance right away. If you‚Äôre told that you need to quarantine, do it right away. If you have symptoms, isolate right away.

Dr. A-Scott: Looking to be aggressive to repeat tests on a regular basis and continue to assess what the risk is and make updates, such as addl PPE and quarantine/isolation measures. Mobile testing units or delivering swabs on site + next day testing.

Dr. A-Scott: Key strategy is preventing the spread by not allowing visitors, isolation for the sick, and quarantine of close contacts. Symptoms can be atypical among seniors. We have been aggressive in determining the potential for C-19 and quarantine and isolation.

Anyone who is tested at the CVS Rapid Testing Site at Twin River will get test results before they leave the site. Anyone who is positive will be contacted by RIDOH. We need to do contact tracing, make sure that you understand the quarantine/isolation:

Social distancing is keeping 6 feet away from others. Quarantine is for people who are not sick, but may have been exposed. Isolation is for people who are sick. Both are about separating people to prevent the spread of disease.

Dr. A-Scott: People also need support from their employers if they are in isolation or quarantine. We need employers to be flexible ; patient. If one of your employees is on quarantine or isolation, they CANNOT be at work.

Dr. A-Scott: If you go into isolation because you are feeling sick, you should stay at home and in isolation for at least 7 days.
On top of that, you need to be fever free for 72 hours without the use of fever reducing medication ; all your symptoms need to have resolved fully.

Dr. A-Scott: If you go into isolation bc you are feeling sick, you should stay home ; in isolation for at least 7 days, be fever free for 3 days w/o fever-reducing meds, all symptoms must resolve completely to be considered clear of any viral infection, including COVID-19.

Dr. A-Scott: We're aware of racial ; ethnic disparities w COVID-19 across the nation. "Your health should not depend on the ZIP code you're from." We understand these disparities occur due to environmental, social, econ. factors. Quarantine/isolation can be even more challenging.

.: Our goal is always to educate first, but we will be breaking up social gatherings and enforcing the executive orders. Fine for violating the social gathering limit is up to $500. We also need mayors + community organizations to help reduce crowds.

.: We are setting up a new unit in the  to crack down on social gatherings. If you see a large social gathering, we‚Äôve set up a hotline specifically for this unit: 401-764-5554. The State Police will be working with local law enforcement + agencies.

.: The 4th metric gives us pause. Today I‚Äôm announcing that we are extending Phase 3 for another 30 days ‚Äì through August 28 ‚Äì with one change to social gatherings. We are lowering the social gathering limit for both indoors and outdoors from 25 to 15 people.

.: RIDOH has done a deep dive into this data, looking through contact tracing at 4,000 positive cases to identify commonalities, and one trend is clear: We're partying too much. Social gatherings continue to be a problem. If you're doing this: Knock it off.

.: One area where we‚Äôre not seeing good enough compliance with our health guidance is at bars and other social gatherings. Inspectors see crowding in bars, restaurants, boats. We‚Äôre seeing new positive cases that we‚Äôre tracing back to backyard parties of 25+ people.

.: We're entering Phase 3 starting tomorrow, but we have a few changes from what was outlined last week to limit large group gatherings. This represents a fair balance. If you planned your wedding in July + are impacted by smaller limits presented today, call 889-5550

.: Increased airflow outside decreases the likelihood of spreading the virus, so larger gatherings can happen outside safely if we maintain social distance. In Phase 3, no cap on number of people in an outdoor setting at one time. We do not recommend going above 250.

.: Social gatherings include all parties, weddings and networking events. There‚Äôs a range here, and we just have to understand that the smaller the group we‚Äôre in, the lower the risk of spreading the virus.

Phase 3 Social Gatherings: 
‚Ä¢ Indoor social gatherings, no more than 50-75. To lower risk, limit to 50 or fewer. There‚Äôs more risk involved with more people, you could go up to 75. 
‚Ä¢ Outdoor social gatherings, no more than 75 to 150 people. Try to limit the gathering to 75.

.: I have ordered a stay at home order for all people in RI. Stay at home, work from your home, go out quickly and occasionally once a week -- alone, not with your whole family. If you have to go to work, go there and go home. RIers are less compliant than those in MA

COVID-19 testing in SA is being expanded to test specific groups of people who either work with vulnerable populations, or who may have less access to testing clinics. Increasing testing will help us protect the community by identifying new cases quickly and preventing outbreaks.
After having a test, people only need to isolate until they recieve a negative test result. Test results are usually available in less than 24 hours.
